etymologies: late Middle English: from petty coat, literally ‘small coat’: the word originally referred to a garment worn by men under a coat or doublet. The second sense derives from a later use to mean ‘skirt’

definitions: a woman's light, loose undergarment hanging from the shoulders or the waist, worn under a skirt or dress.
shortDefinitions: woman's light, loose undergarment hanging from shoulders or waist

definitions: used to denote female control of something regarded as more commonly dominated by men

examples.text: he was in danger of succumbing to the petticoat government of Mary and Sarah

shortDefinitions: used to denote female control of something regarded as more commonly dominated by men
